@jinfengni, Can you please close this pull request? The issue https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CALCITE-628 has been fixed.
Please don't put spaces at ends of lines: "... \n". You end up with spaces at ends of lines in RelOptRulesTest.xml, and then later there are spurious diffs when someone's IDE removes the spaces.
These are all minor nits. I have fixed them and rebased and will commit when the tests pass.
Thanks Julian!
Associated [JIRA](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CALCITE-823).
Looks like nice work... I'll review thoroughly and get back to you... let me know whether you expect to add more or whether this is complete.

I left the `zip` and `createOrderedEnumerable` unimplemented, because these two method I do not clearly understand its mechanism, but I'll fill it as fast as I can.
This stage my target is only finishing the `Enumerable` only, the `Queryable` and `Expression` have not been considered.

I get a couple of build errors on JDK 1.8:

```
[ERROR] /home/jhyde/open1/calcite.2/core/src/main/java/org/apache/calcite/prepare/QueryableRelBuilder.java:[77,1] org.apache.calcite.prepare.QueryableRelBuilder is not abstract and does not override abstract method <TKey,TResult>groupByK(org.apache.calcite.linq4j.Queryable<T>,org.apache.calcite.linq4j.tree.FunctionExpression<org.apache.calcite.linq4j.function.Function1<T,TKey>>,org.apache.calcite.linq4j.tree.FunctionExpression<org.apache.calcite.linq4j.function.Function2<TKey,org.apache.calcite.linq4j.Enumerable<T>,TResult>>) in org.apache.calcite.linq4j.QueryableFactory
[ERROR] /home/jhyde/open1/calcite.2/core/src/main/java/org/apache/calcite/prepare/QueryableRelBuilder.java:[318,61] <TKey,TResult>groupByK(org.apache.calcite.linq4j.Queryable<T>,org.apache.calcite.linq4j.tree.FunctionExpression<org.apache.calcite.linq4j.function.Function1<T,TKey>>,org.apache.calcite.linq4j.tree.FunctionExpression<org.apache.calcite.linq4j.function.Function2<TKey,org.apache.calcite.linq4j.Enumerable<T>,TResult>>) in org.apache.calcite.prepare.QueryableRelBuilder cannot implement <TKey,TResult>groupByK(org.apache.calcite.linq4j.Queryable<T>,org.apache.calcite.linq4j.tree.FunctionExpression<org.apache.calcite.linq4j.function.Function1<T,TKey>>,org.apache.calcite.linq4j.tree.FunctionExpression<org.apache.calcite.linq4j.function.Function2<TKey,org.apache.calcite.linq4j.Enumerable<T>,TResult>>) in org.apache.calcite.linq4j.QueryableFactory
  return type org.apache.calcite.linq4j.Queryable<org.apache.calcite.linq4j.Grouping<TKey,TResult>> is not compatible with org.apache.calcite.linq4j.Queryable<TResult>
[INFO] 2 errors 
```
I can pass the `mvn package -pl 'linq4j'`, let me check is that any errors.

Seems found errors, I did only build the standalone linq4j project, but not considered the projects depend on it.
The errors is caused by the signature of `groupBy` method changed, I compared with the .NET Linq code and found some incorrect return type and method parameters. I don't know whether that methods is really incorrect or my misunderstand, if my mistake, please point it out, I'll fix it.

If I recall correctly, I renamed one of the overloads of `groupBy` to `groupByK` because Java erases generic types before resolving overloads. You can't have say `String foo(List<String> ls)` and `int foo(List<Integer> li)` because both are `foo(List)` after erasure. .NET doesn't have this problem because it has reified types.

Em... I understand the intend that `groupByK` method naming. The method signature I said is the return value of some `groupBy` methods in `Enumerable`.
Such as an overloads in the `ExtendedEnumerable` is declared with (@696da16 ExtendedEnumerable:369)

``` java
 <TKey, TElement> Enumerable<Grouping<TKey, TElement>> groupBy(
    Function1<TSource, TKey> keySelector,
    Function2<TKey, Enumerable<TSource>, TResult> elementSelector);
```

but the type of the parameter `elementSelector`, in the linq of C#, is used for `resultSelector`, and the method should return `Enumerable<TResult>` instead of the `Enumerable<Grouping<TKey, TElement>>`, because the grouped elements has been already aggregated by the `resultSelector`.

So, I changed this method's signature to: (@9fcf751 ExtendedEnumerable:379)

``` java
<TKey, TResult> Enumerable<TResult> groupBy(
    Function1<TSource, TKey> keySelector,
    Function2<TKey, Enumerable<TSource>, TResult> resultSelector);
```

and then caused chain reaction.
Try this instead: https://github.com/julianhyde/incubator-calcite/tree/886-group-by-system-function.

Did you run the unit test JdbcTest.testRunAgg()?

Actually, initially I tried the same code as you did, and it regressed in testRunAgg().  

Here is the part of the failed stack trace:

> Caused by: java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException: class org.apache.calcite.sql.SqlNodeList: 
>   at org.apache.calcite.util.Util.needToImplement(Util.java:920)
>   at org.apache.calcite.sql.validate.SqlValidatorImpl$DeriveTypeVisitor.visit(SqlValidatorImpl.java:4199)

You're right. I guess GROUPING SETS isn't an expression (it doesn't have a type). I think the fix is for validateGroupClause to call validate on calls to GROUPING SETS, CUBE, ROLLUP and validateExpr on everything else. Please see my branch.

It looks good. This should solve the problem for now. Thanks!

As a second thought, if only SqlIdentifier has different handling for validate() and validateExpr(), the other SqlNode itself does not have difference, will it make sense to 1) remove validateExpr() from SqlNode interface, 2) SqlIdentifier will internally call validateExpr() for validate() call, 3) all the callers call SqlNode.validate()?

I seem to recall a problem with USING, e.g. `select * from emp join dept using (deptno)`. Here you are validating deptno as an identifier, not as an expression. So it helps to pass in the context, i.e. what you want the node to be.
I committed this as https://github.com/apache/incubator-calcite/commit/02cfd7fdacb2f43ed06f2ebb32cf3205ca26df95. Thanks for this patch! High quality work.

I am grad contributing to this project. BTW, I saw the new code used the new features of Java7 , try-with-resource and diamond operator, is the lamdba expression (Java8) is permitted to use too? Some codes write with lambda will be more efficiently.

Currently our code level is 1.7. So we can use try-with-resources but not lambdas. Lambdas are awesome, but our community wants compatibility with 1.7.

Of course if you use Calcite or Linq4j in an application that only runs in JDK 1.8, in which case you can use lambdas.

OK, I got that, I'll continue keeping the compatibility with 1.7 when implementing the `createOrderedEnumerable`. But the complexity of the `OrderedEnumearble` is more higher than my expectation, maybe I will spent a long time on it.

To continue our conversation about JDK 1.7 versus JDK 1.8. Since JDK 1.8 has default methods for interfaces it is possible that EnumerableDefaults and QueryableDefaults could just go away when we discontinue support for JDK 1.7.
Have a more general implementation. :)

Does this rule work if you remove the check for duplicate sorts? In volcano planner the rule will be fired many more times than it needs to be - and will still generate duplicate sorts, which will then be removed by the canonization check.

Can you add a negative test to make sure that limit is not erroneously pushed through inner join? It could be in join.oq.

The rule could in principle fire for full join, but I can see that is not very important.

I would use com.google.common.base.Objects.equals() to test fetch and offset in sortEquals because null-safe equality is such a common pattern.
I meant make the whole thing a shuttle, and use the shuttle's support for scanning arg lists and rebuilding calls, like this: https://github.com/julianhyde/incubator-calcite/tree/895-case-push

@julianhyde , thanks for the comments.
1. If I remove the check for duplicate sorts, the rule was firing forever in the HepPlanner tests. In order to avoid that, you could put SortMergeRule in the same group. Thus, the discussion is between 1) creating a rule that is valid on its own, or 2) one that has dependencies with some other rules. I guess I prefer option 1), what's your take?
2. testSortJoinTranspose3 is already a negative test. I will add another negative one with a sort on the inner input.
3. For full join, I'm wondering about the implications of possibly having nulls in the sorting columns? Probably it is safe to push it for full join iff Sort consists of a "naked" limit? I'll think further on it, and update the rule accordingly before we commit it.
4. I will update the pull request to use com.google.common.base.Objects.equals().

Re 1. I prefer (1) also but I wouldn't do it by making the rule look for particular types of RelNode. Nor do I want the rule to behave differently in different engines. It's a hard problem that we haven't solved yet but my suspicion is that metadata is the solution. If we can look at a RelNode - without knowing its type - and know that it will not produce more than 10 rows, then we know we don't need to apply limit(10). Similarly, metadata for uniqueness can prevent us from pushing aggregates too many times.

Suppose you ran SortJoinTransposeRule and FilterSortTransposeRule in the same Hep program. It would repeatedly push a sort through the join, then through the underlying filter. Your strategy of looking for Sort on the inputs would fail, and the program would loop. Therefore I think we need a more robust way to find out whether a rule has been fired, and the answer is metadata - because metadata has a monotonicity property.

That said I think implementing a new kind of metadata is hard, and until https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CALCITE-794 is fixed if we lean hard on metadata it will bite us.

Re 2. I missed that case. I still think it's useful to add something to join.oq. Then we get to see whether these plans actually work.

Re 3. I can see how full join would cause problems if you had 'order by deptno nulls first limit 3', and limiting the input would cause false-positive nulls to appear. I think the right answer is a comment that we haven't figured out full join yet.

Re 4. Great.

Comments:
1. In the rule patten specification, why do you specify the join left / right child?  
   I think in onMatch() method, you could get the left/right child from the join node directly, in stead of from RelOptRuleCall. 
2. For Left/right outer join,  if sort does not have collation, then seems we could remove the sort on top of join; the sort pushed into either left or right side will ensure we get exactly the # of rows we want.

Counter-example to 2:

``` sql
select * from emp left join dept using (deptno) limit 3
```

and consider that emp and dept each have 5 rows with deptno = 10. The left join ensures that there is _at least_ one dept per emp but it does not ensure that there is _at most_ one. Your proposed rewrite to

``` sql
select *
from (select * from emp limit 3)
left join (select * from dept limit 3) using (deptno)
```

would return 9 rows for deptno = 10.
For comment 2: You are right.  We could not remove Sort on top of Join.

Thanks for your comments.

@jinfengni , the only reason to specify them is that I want to get the class of the RelNode, and I would not like to use e.g. a cast to HepRelVertex to get the RelNode, as this would make the rule incompatible with Volcano planner. I'm working on a version of the rule that gets rid of this matching by relying on MD providers.

@julianhyde , new commit relies on MD providers instead of casting. Could you check it again?

I added the test to join.oq and the rule does not apply. The reason is that in Enumerable, Limit and Sort are different operators. I have left the test and a comment on why it does not apply.

@julianhyde , continuing with our previous conversation, what about checking this fix in (so the RelOptUtil method cannot produce duplicate column names), and creating a follow up JIRA case to change the method that AggregateProjectMergeRule calls? I think it makes sense.

I might be mistaken, but it looks as if the code does basic authentication even if user and password as not specified. Is this what we want?

Can a user choose not to use basic authentication?

Do we need some changes to http://calcite.apache.org/docs/avatica_overview.html ? At least "basic authentication" on the "Implemented" list.

This change needs some tests, including one where the password is valid, another where it is invalid, and another where user name and password are not specified.

`SqlDialect` objects are immutable, and we should keep them that way. So, can you remove the `useFetch` and `useOffsetOnly` fields. I think it's sufficient to have a single method `supportsOffsetFetch()` which returns true by default (i.e. compliant with SQL 2008; see https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CALCITE-43). MySQL would override and return false, which means that it uses LIMIT syntax instead.

I think you need to combine the `offset` and `fetch` methods into `offsetFetch(SqlNode offset, SqlNode fetch)` because you want to generate `OFFSET n ROWS FETCH NEXT n ROWS` for SQL-compliant databases and `LIMIT n OFFSET n` for the rest. Note that OFFSET occurs first in one, second in the other.
Thanks for your comments Julian. I have incorporated them and updated PR. Its open for review again.

Thanks for the quick glance @vlsi !
Just pushed two more commits. One gives a better exception in JdbcMeta and the other is a test for setting nulls in JdbcMeta (in the batch and non-batch paths). Thanks against, Vladimir!

@joshelser, regarding null values, consider the following:
Case 1) Stored procedure `proc(p_arg number)`, `proc(p_arg varchar)`, etc
Which one would be called if using just `setObject(1, null)`?

Case 2) Consider a statement `select id, name from entities where id=?`.
Do you think execution plan would be different in case of `setInt(1, 42)` vs `setString(1, "42")`?
You might ask me something like "wait a minute, case 2 does not involve nulls". If that is the case, think twice )

Uhh, wrong user mention there, Vladimir. I'm @joshelser.

>  Which one would be called if using just setObject(1, null)?

But the types of the parameters in the statement are already defined at this point. We're just setting binding a value -- this isn't defining the type of that value.

> Do you think execution plan would be different in case of setInt(1, 42) vs setString(1, "42")?
> You might ask me something like "wait a minute, case 2 does not involve nulls". If that is the case, think twice )

I really don't follow what you're trying to tell me. Can you phrase your concern by not asking me a question?

> But the types of the parameters in the statement are already defined at this point. We're just setting binding a value -- this isn't defining the type of that value.

Can you please pin-point where the type is defined?
Do you mean this setObject(.., null) will eventually be translated to proper `setNull(..., sqltype)`?

> Can you phrase your concern by not asking me a question?

My concern is this setObject: https://github.com/apache/calcite/pull/209/files#diff-39e8b3d56f84afa3fbffe40bed7cbbc2R895 does not convey data type properly.

Failing to specify data type causes performance degradation for major RDBMS (e.g. Oracle, PostgreSQL). For instance, PostgreSQL cannot efficiently batch statements if data type of a column changes from row to row.

> Can you please pin-point where the type is defined?

I thought that the PreparedStatement is going to know when this value can be coerced into whatever the necessary value at runtime is. Maybe I'm assuming too much on what will happen behind the scenes.

> Failing to specify data type causes performance degradation for major RDBMS (e.g. Oracle, PostgreSQL). For instance, PostgreSQL cannot efficiently batch statements if data type of a column changes from row to row.

But is this case any different than what is already done in `JdbcMeta`? https://github.com/apache/calcite/blob/master/avatica/server/src/main/java/org/apache/calcite/avatica/jdbc/JdbcMeta.java#L795-L800 I can understand where you're coming from, but this seems like a larger issue than just my changeset.

> value can be coerced into whatever the necessary value at runtime is

That is a typical JDBC user's pitfall.
All java's nulls are equals. You cannot tell the difference between `(Integer) null` vs `(String) null`.
That is why `setNull` is really important.

> this seems like a larger issue than just my changeset

.. which is fine if we'll get better performance out of `setObject(int, Object, int)`. We should just make sure that we make that change everywhere and add tests if it is functionally incorrect or ambiguous (I'm not sure anymore if you're saying it's incorrect or just not as performant as it could be).

> But is this case any different than what is already done in JdbcMeta?

1) I do not track 100% of Calcite development.
2) I'm known to bug people, often for no reason. Sorry about that.
3) I've been bitten by those `setObject(, null)` bugs multiple times.
4) I had some spare 20 minutes to go through the changeset.

That is why I just highlighted the issue here.

> (I'm not sure anymore if you're saying it's incorrect or just not as performant as it could be).

Both apply.

> Case 1) Stored procedure proc(p_arg number), proc(p_arg varchar), etc

In such a case, "prepared statement" would fail with null argument since database would have no way to pick the proper procedure. That is functional issue. The query would fail with SQLException instead of execution of proper procedure with null argument.
Well, it is not that often, however, it might be an issue since that is typical use for "argument overloading".

> Case 2)

Performance issue: if type of bind value changes over time (e.g. `setObject(1, (Integer)42)`, and later `setObject(1, null)`), database has to replan the query or split the batch, etc.

> which is fine if we'll get better performance out of setObject(int, Object, int)

I'm not sure how struct/array/SQLData types are supported, if supported at all.
In those cases, `setNull(int parameterIndex, int sqlType, String typeName)` would be required to propagate sql typeName.

> 1) I do not track 100% of Calcite development.

That's why I sent you a link to the code :). We're doing the same thing in other areas of the code. Thanks for bringing it up.

This sounds to me like a limitation of how Avatica is handling types in PreparedStatements. Can you write this up in a JIRA issue? I can try to do it, but I don't want to misrepresent the issues (as I apparently don't fully understand the nitty-gritty details of the problem). If not, I can try copy-pasting what you've already typed up here. I just want to make sure that we don't lose the fact that we should try to address this.

> should just make sure that we make that change everywhere

It might be just fine to add some `// TODO: fix before 2018-18-18` comment (or create a jira ticket) in order to keep that under control.

I just wanted to limit the danger. If it is possible to implement that properly already, it would be better to go that way. At later stages it could be harder to fix the issue due to "backward compatibility", etc, etc.

Ok. I think you've got my point.
Method javadoc needs to use third person throughout. Sorry to be pedantic.
